article.description: Andre Emmet had 23 points and eight rebounds and Texas Tech held off Minnesota 71-61 in the NIT consolation game Thursday night.

related.description: After Texas Tech held off Minnesota 71-61 in the NIT consolation game Thursday night, Bob Knight positively gushed about rescued POW Army Pfc. Jessica Lynch. Her convoy was attacked March 23 after making a wrong turn in southern Iraq.
related.linkText: Knight has nothing but praise for rescued POW
related.title: 'General' heaps praise on rescued POW Lynch
related.headline: 'General' heaps praise on rescued POW Lynch

related.description:
Marcus Hatten scored 22 points and made a key free throw as St. John's
won its record sixth National Invitational Tournament with a 70-67
comeback victory over Big East rival Georgetown
related.linkText: Hatten's 22 points lead St. John's to NIT title
related.title: Hatten-led Red Storm capture sixth NIT title
related.headline: Hatten-led Red Storm capture sixth NIT title

images.name: Hatten Marcus 030403 horiz top
images.caption: Marcus Hatten was the toast of New York on Thursday.

article.headline: Red Raiders fend off late Minnesota rally
article.linkText: Texas Tech holds off Minnesota for third in NIT
article.story: MINNEAPOLIS (AP) -- Minnesota coach Dan Monson didn't call time outs and ordered the Golden Gophers not to take three-point shots, just to see how they would react in their exhibition game against the Pulley Panthers. The Gophers responded by nearly blowing a 21-point lead to the team of former college players, hanging on to win 84-71 on Wednesday. "To go out and get exposed helps you learn," said Monson, whose team hosts Missouri-Kansas City Monday night in the first round of the preseason NIT. "We're in jeopardy of going into the NIT and going one and out," said Monson, grumbling that the Gophers were slow going after loose balls, while leaving the Panthers open for long-range shots that got them back into the game. "You're not going to always be sharp this time of year, but we've got to play with a little more passion, we've got to play with a little bit more sense of urgency than I think we had," he said. The Gophers started out the game making five straight three-point shots, three coming from Ben Johnson, on the way to a 45-24 lead. But the Panthers made seven of their first 12 shots in the second half, and trailed 55-52 with 12:23 remaining in the game. "You can learn something every night," said Adam Boone, who scored 19 points. "We could have easily crumbled, but I was proud of the fact that we were able to hold them off and get the win." Johnson also wound up with 19 points for Minnesota, while Kris Humphries had 12 points and 12 rebounds, with Michael Bauer adding 11 and Stan Gaines 10. Demetrius Walker led the Panthers with 20 points, with Mike Walker adding 12. Minnesota and the Panthers matched baskets in the early going, with Ken Maxey's shot tying the game at 16-16. The Gophers went ahead for good on Boone's layup, building the lead to 45-26 by holding the Panthers scoreless for nearly five minutes. After the Panthers closed to within three points in the second half, they managed to keep the game close, trailing by just 72-68 on Mike Walker's three-pointer with 3:27 remaining. The Gophers finally pushed their lead to double digits at 78-68 on a pair of free throws by Bauer with 53 seconds left. "We just got to play better than that," said Bauer. "If we can fix it, it's great to be exposed now because nothing counts."
